) is a sea-side town of about 20,000 residents located 32km (20 miles) north of

Balbriggan is well-positioned for visitors who wish to access Dublin city, while glimpsing rural life and exploring the North-East of Ireland. It's a good base for touring, with the possibility of day-trips to
, accessing the Cooley peninsula, the mountains of Mourne and its capital city of
. Closer to home are many sacred centres such as the Hill of Tara, Knowth, Dowth, Newgrange and Mellifont Abbey.
The village of Balbriggan lends itself beautifully to walking - all locations within the village are easily accessible by foot.

value: content=This church contains two stained-glass windows created by Harry Clarke:

1) The Widow's Son: A two-light window to the left of the altar, depicting the widow from Nain and her son in the main panel of the first light, and the figure of Jesus wearing dark ruby robes in the main panel of the second light.

2) The Visitation: A two-light window situated on the south wall, depicting Mary’s visit to her cousin, Elisabeth. A youthful Mary is depicted in the main panel of the first light and the main panel of the second light portrays the older, visibly pregnant Elizabeth.

content=Slowly being restored, Bremore Castle is a large tower house estimated to have been built in the 14th century. Although the castle itself is not accessible to the public, there are car-parking facilities in front with easy access by foot to a good beach walk, northwards to Gormanstown or southwards to Balbriggan town itself.

content=Set in extensive park lands overlooking the Irish Sea with a view of the Mourne Mountains. Castle and/or garden tours, Medieval stocks and Tudor stand-ins, wheelchair friendly Tea Rooms, Holistic centre on site, state-of-the-art children’s playground, cycle and walking paths.
content=A cultural centre dedicated to Séamus Ennis, Uilleann Piper, Folklore and Music Collector.
content=UNESCO World Heritage Site. Neolithic chamber tombs.

content=A premier parkland course recently redesigned by Eddie Connaughton with USGA standard sand based greens and tee boxes. The blend of mature trees and newly designed water hazards, which come into play on seven holes, give an intriguing character to the course and provides golfers with variety and a challenging round.
content=Set dancing.  Tin whistle and fiddle classes
content=A multi activity centre for all age groups. Activities include high ropes, archery, off road buggies, paintball, zip lines and much more. Advance booking essential.

content=The club controls the rights to Wavin Lake and the Delvin River. Wavin Lake (26 acre site), stocked with rainbow trout is Dublin's largest all year fishery, primarily promoting fly fishing. The Delvin River has a good run of brown and sea trout. Day tickets can be purchased for both fisheries: lake €10 (with member), river €20.
content=Clay shooting and rifle shooting; archery; trout fishing; gun room and shop; Café and bar.
content=Upstairs in the popular Harvest Inn bar and lounge - American diner inspired eating
content=Authentic Thai cuisine. Emphasis on good food, with no "additives".
content=Café by day, wine and tapas bar by night. Relaxed dining. Live music Friday and Saturday nights. Free Wi-Fi.
content=Well-appointed restaurant in the Bracken Court Hotel.

All of the drinking establishments in Balbriggan are well-run, being both individual and family friendly.

value: content=Photographs on walls depict history of Balbriggan. Spacious billiard (snooker/pool) area.
